importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the news article's publication indicates the most up-to-date information about the crash investigation, allowing the public to understand the current status of the NTSB's preliminary report.
The date of the crash is central to the incident timeline and helps contextualize the events leading up to the crash within the broader timeline of aviation safety and air traffic control procedures.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The geographical location of the crash provides context for regional aviation safety and emergency response protocols in rural areas of the southeastern U.S.

keyTakeAways: Brett James, a Grammy-winning songwriter, died in a plane crash on September 18, 2025, in Franklin, North Carolina, after his aircraft entered a tightening spiral.
The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) preliminary report indicates the plane did not have mechanical issues, pointing to a possible pilot or communication error.
James requested a visual approach to runway 7, which air traffic control approved, but failed to tune to the common traffic advisory frequency, leading to a loss of communication.
The controller attempted to communicate that James had not changed the radio frequency, but there were no further transmissions.

James had a significant career in music, collaborating with major artists such as Taylor Swift, Bon Jovi, Keith Urban, and Kenny Chesney, notably co-writing the song 'Out Last Night' and the song 'Jesus, Take the Wheel' for Carrie Underwood.
His death is notable because it underscores the risks in general aviation and the importance of proper communication protocols in flight operations.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Grammy-winning songwriter Brett James, 57, died in a plane crash on September 18, 2025, when his Cirrus SR22T aircraft entered a tightening spiral after failing to maintain proper radio communication with air traffic control. The NTSB's preliminary report found no mechanical issues, indicating that the incident likely stemmed from a communication error — James never changed from his initial frequency despite being instructed to tune to the common traffic advisory frequency. He had requested a visual approach to runway 7, which was approved, but his failure to communicate his position after that led to a loss of contact. The crash occurred in Franklin, North Carolina, about 270 miles southeast of Nashville, killing all three people on board. James was a highly respected songwriter who collaborated with major artists like Taylor Swift, Bon Jovi, Keith Urban, and Kenny Chesney, notably co-writing 'Out Last Night' and 'Jesus, Take the Wheel' for Carrie Underwood. His death raises concerns about safety protocols in general aviation and the importance of adherence to standard flight communication practices.
title: Songwriter Brett James’ Plane Crashes, Entering Tightening Spiral Before Impact
